Award.AwardTitle: Force Transduction Mechanisms At Adherens Junctions

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Mechanical forces are major determinants of cell and tissue development. During tissue development, cells experience numerous mechanical forces including tensile or compressive forces from shape change of the surrounding tissues and shear force from fluid flow in tubular structures. In the lining of the lungs, blood vessels and the kidney cells that line tubular structures adhere directly to their neighbors by junctions that join the fibrous internal cellular cytoskeleton. The cell-to-cell connections transmit forces between the cells. The intercellular connections are part of how lung, kidney and vascular lining cells can measure the forces of fluid flow or air pressure. The objective of this research is to mimic how the forces of fluid flow are coupled to the cell-cell junctions and how they cause cell structural changes in the cells that make them function properly. Failure of cells properly to sense and transmit mechanical signals can cause progression of diseases of the kidney, vasculature and lung.

Our understanding of force transmission pathways has been limited due to a lack of tools to measure forces in specific proteins in live cells. This research will use a novel approach of combining FRET based force sensors with microfluidics that presents an opportunity to establish the link between flow-induced cytoskeletal forces and adherens junction (AJ) dynamics responsible for cell remodeling. The distribution of cytoskeletal force and its time-dependence for specific proteins will be mapped using FRET probes in cells subjected to flow stimuli. Adherens junction dynamics will be measured simultaneously with fluorescently labeled junction proteins. The outcome of this research will be a new understanding of the dynamics of shear force transduction in living cells, and perhaps most importantly, a measure of the cause and effect relationships of energy flow in the cell. The FRET force probes would also provide a new research toolset to the scientific community to study cell mechanics. The educational broader impacts will be accomplished through a unique program on Education through Experimentation or E2E

Intellectual Merits:

Epithelial cells utilize mechanical stimuli such as shear stresses as signals to activate a continuous remodeling process that enables maintenance of epithelium integrity. This project investigated how forces due to fluid flow are transmitted in cells, causing dynamic cell remodeling. The research has led to several significant outcomes.

Utilizing our novel approach of combining FRET based force sensors with microfluidics, we have demonstrated for the first time that fluid shear stress is transmitted to adherens junctions (AJs) through a heterogeneous distribution of cytoskeletal forces. Changes in cytoskeletal tension and reorganization precedes the dynamic remodeling of cytoskeleton and adherens junctions. We developed a novel microfluidic platform to study the role of E-cadherin (the core structural protein of AJs) on the essential physiological process, the collective cell migration. We found that epithelial cells rely on lateral E-cad adhesions to maintain cohesion of the group. These adhesions transmit the shear forces but do not provide a driving force for the migration. These results delineate the shear stress transduction paths in epithelial cells. 

We then focused on identification of force sensors that are on the frontlines of force transduction in epithelial cells. We discovered that Piezo1, a mechanosensitive ion channel, is the primary flow sensors responsible for epithelial cell remodeling. Fluid shear stress causes changes in cell nuclear shape through activation of Piezo1 channels that function via Ca2+ signaling. Inhibiting Piezo1 channels or knockdown Piezo1 with miRNA eliminates nucleus shrinkage. The nuclear deformation under shear stress is Ca2+ dependent as supplied by Piezo1. Moreover, Piezo1 mediated Ca2+ elevation is adequate for both shear stress induced nuclear changes and actin reorganization. These results emphasize the role of mechanosensitive channels as the primary transducers in force transmission.

Using this technology, we also studied the response of brain cells to shear forces during traumatic brain injury (TBI). We discovered that a uniform shear force can generate a heterogeneous distribution of cytoskeletal forces in single cells, in both time and space. The cytoskeletal forces and their modulation on cell membrane tension open mechanosensitive channels that result in Ca2+ influx. The shear force is transmitted via modulation of mechanosensitive channels. These results are significant, because the early cell response plays a critical role in the subsequent pathology and the progression of TBI.

The research findings have been reported in seven journal papers including Scientific Reports and Journal of Cell Science.

Broader Impacts:

Educational impacts: This NSF grant provided training to 8 graduate and undergraduate students (five Ph.D. students, one M.S. student, and two undergraduates). These include five from the underrepresented groups (women and minorities). Two PhD students have obtained their degrees and joined leading Biotech companies; others have continued pursuing their degrees. The undergraduate students have gained sufficient knowledge and skills in advance technologies including microfluidics, micropatterning, and live cell imaging, and co-authored journal and proceedings papers. They are on track to pursue higher degrees (MD/Ph.D.) at leading institutes.

Scientific impacts: Identifying proteins that directly sense and respond to external forces is an important step in understanding mechanotransduction process that lead to cell remodeling under various local environments. The significance of this research exceeds macroscopic sources of cell remodeling under flow. It provides the important insights for force transduction in epithelia.

In terms of technological Impacts, PIs’ novel approach of combining their novel FRET based force sensors with microfluidics has opened a grand opportunity to establish the link between flow-induced cytoskeletal forces and cell remodeling. The technique has been successfully adapted to studies in other biosystems that encounter mechanical forces, such as, brain cells during TBI.
